metadata.title: High frequency of SARS-CoV-2 RNAemia and association with severe disease 2 3

abstract.text: Background: Detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in the blood, also known as RNAemia, has been 25 reported, but its prognostic implications are not well understood. This study aimed to determine 26 the frequency of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in plasma and its association with the clinical severity of 27 Methods: An analytical cross-sectional study was performed in a single-center tertiary care 29 institution in northern California and included consecutive inpatients and outpatients with COVID-30 19 confirmed by detection of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in nasopharyngeal swab specimens. The 31 prevalence of SARS CoV-2 RNAemia and the strength of its association with clinical severity 32 variables were examined and included the need for transfer to an intensive care unit (ICU), 33 mechanical ventilation and 30-day all-cause mortality.

34 Results: Paired nasopharyngeal and plasma samples were included from 85 patients. The overall 35 median age was 55 years, and individuals with RNAemia were older than those with undetectable 36 SARS-CoV-2 RNA in plasma (63 vs 50 years; p=0.001). Comorbidities were frequent including 37 obesity (37.7%), hypertension (30.6%) and diabetes mellitus (22.4%). RNAemia was detected in 38 a total of 28/85 (32.9%) individual patients, including 22/28 (78.6%) who required hospital 39 admission. RNAemia was detected more frequently in individuals who developed severe disease 40 including the need for ICU transfer (32.1% vs 14.0%; p=0.05), mechanical ventilation (21.4% vs 41 3.5%; p=0.01) and 30-day all-cause mortality (14.3% vs 0%; p=0.01). No association was detected 42 between RNAemia and estimated levels of viral RNA in the nasopharynx. An additional 121 43 plasma samples from 28 individuals with RNAemia were assessed longitudinally, and RNA was 44 detected for a maximum duration of 10 days.

This study demonstrated a high proportion of SARS-CoV-2 RNAemia, and an 46 association between RNAemia and clinical severity suggesting the potential utility of plasma viral 47 testing as a prognostic indicator for COVID-19. 48 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. : medRxiv preprint 95 did mortality (14.3% vs 0%; p=0.01). All 4 deaths occurred in individuals with RNAemia. A total 96 of 15/17 (88.2%) plasma samples with presence of RNAemia in severely ill patients were collected 97 prior to or on the same day as their ICU transfer. For the 16 individuals with suspected community-98 acquired COVID-19 admitted to the ICU, time from hospital admission to the ICU was short with 99 13/16 (81.3%) transferred on the same day or within 1 day of admission. No association was 100 detected between estimated viral loads in the nasopharynx, as estimated by RT-PCR Ct value, and 101 detection of RNAemia. Furthermore, plasma E gene Ct values were high which is consistent with 102 low viral burden, with a median of 37.5 (IQR 35.1-39.6).

103 104 An additional 121 plasma samples from the 28 individuals with RNAemia detected on the paired 105 plasma sample were tested to assess longitudinal trends. Each individual underwent a median of 2 106 (IQR 0-7) repeat SARS-CoV-2 plasma tests, with a range of 1 to 27 days between tests. The longest 107 period of RNAemia was 10 days and occurred in an ICU-admitted patient. SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR 108 Ct values were comparable to those seen in the initial paired samples with a median of 37.2 (IQR 109 34.6-39.6). Detailed paired NP and plasma values are presented in Figure 1 for the individuals 110 with 5 or more longitudinal samples including one sample collected prior to ICU transfer. 111 112 Discussion 113 This analytical cross-sectional study assessed 85 individual with a nasopharyngeal swab positive 114 for SARS-CoV-2 RNA for detection of RNAemia in paired plasma samples. Thse findings show 115 that RNAemia was present in almost one third of samples tested. This proportion is higher than 116 previously reported from a cohort of COVID-19-positive individuals in China, where only 3/307 127 reported to occur in up to 75% of plasma samples between 5 and 7 days of illness, and up to 78% 128 of serum samples on admission. 12-14 129 130
The association between RNAemia, ICU transfer and mechanical ventilation observed in this study 131 suggests the potential utility of plasma SARS-CoV-2 RNA testing as a prognostic indicator.

Indeed, although this study was not performed in a controlled setting, most (88.2%) plasma 133 samples with presence of RNAemia in severely ill patients were collected prior to or on the same 134 day as their ICU transfer, supporting a possible role for the early detection of at-risk individuals. 135 Preliminary data from a limited number of patients have shown an association between RNAemia 136 and severe COVID-19, and support the presence of RNA in extra-pulmonary sites. 11 A similar 137 association between detection of SARS-CoV-1 RNA in serum and clinical complications including 138 oxygen desaturation, mechanical ventilation and mortality was noted in 2004. 15 Thus, plasma may 139 All rights reserved. body_text.text: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is most frequently diagnosed from nasopharyngeal 50 (NP) swab samples. Preliminary data suggest that severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 51 2 (SARS-CoV-2) RNA may also be detected in plasma and serum. 1,2 However, the frequency and 52 prognostic implication of viral RNA detection in these sample types is not fully understood. We 53 aim to investigate the association between detectable SARS-CoV-2 RNA in nasopharyngeal swab 54 and plasma samples, and to describe clinical implications of viral RNA detection in plasma. was not certified by peer review) is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

A total of 7,240 samples from SHC patients were tested for SARS-CoV-2 corresponding to 4,485 82 outpatients, 2,452 ED patients, and 303 inpatients, and 453 (6.3%) were positive. Of these, 85 83 individuals with paired NP and plasma samples were included for analysis (Table 1 ). BIBREF0.title: Antibody response and viraemia during the course of severe 192 acute respiratory syndrome (SARS)-associated coronavirus infection

BIBREF1.title: Detection of severe acute respiratory syndrome 195 coronavirus RNA in plasma during the course of infection

BIBREF2.title: Detection of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 198 in blood of infected patients

BIBREF3.title: Viral loads in clinical specimens and SARS 200 manifestations

FIGREF0.text: performed a cross-sectional study at the Stanford Health Care (SHC) Clinical Virology 58 Laboratory, which serves adult and pediatric tertiary care hospitals and affiliated primary care and 59 specialty clinics in northern California. From the beginning of in-house SARS-CoV-2 testing on 60 March 2 2020, residual EDTA whole blood was systematically collected from all SHC patients 61 with a respiratory sample positive for SARS-CoV-2 RNA. NP samples collected with detectable 62 SARS-CoV-2 RNA between March 2 2020 and April 8 2020 were identified and included in the 63 study if residual EDTA whole blood had been collected within 72 hours before or after the NP 64 collection. If available, residual whole blood samples from serial collections, with or without 65 paired NP samples, were also included in the analysis. A volume of 400µL of EDTA plasma from 66 the residual whole blood was extracted and processed to assess for SARS-CoV-2 RNA. Testing 67 was performed based on the adaptation of published rRT-PCR assays targeting the envelope (E) 68 gene. 3-5 The standard cycle threshold (Ct) values of positive tests with this assay range from <20 69 to 45 cycles. Confirmatory testing of all plasma samples with a Ct value of 40 or greater was 70 performed and resulted as positive if reproducible. 4 Given that viral culture was not performed to 71 All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF1.text: 84 median age was 55 years (inter-quartile range (IQR) 40-69) and only two pediatric cases met 85 inclusion criteria, aged 9 and 17 years. Individuals with detectable RNAemia were significantly 86 older than those without RNAemia (63 vs 50 years; p=0.001). Comorbidities were prevalent 87 including obesity in 32/85 (37.6%), hypertension in 26/85 (30.6%) and diabetes mellitus in 19/85 88 (22.4%); no association was detected between each comorbidity and RNAemia. The overall 89 median number of days of symptoms at the time of NP testing was 7 days (IQR 4-12) and was 90 similar in individuals with and without RNAemia. The most common symptoms were cough 91 (87.1%) and fever (69.8%). RNAemia was detected in a total of 28/85 (32.9%) patients. ICU 92 transfer occurred significantly more frequently in individuals with RNAemia compared to those 93 with undetectable SARS-CoV-2 RNA in plasma (32.1% vs 14.0%; p=0.05). FIGREF2.text: , direct comparison of these results is challenging due to the use of different 120 testing protocols, including differences in specimen extraction volumes (ranging from 80 to 121 200L), sample types examined (plasma, serum and whole blood), viral genomic targets tested (N, 122 S, E or ORF1ab genes), variable timing of blood collection relative to symptom chronology and 123 different patient populations. For example, using the most similar plasma RT-PCR method to this 124 study as a comparator, the higher prevalence of RNAemia may be explained by the higher 125 proportion of individuals with severe disease in this cohort (ICU transfer 20.0% vs 11.1%). 8 By 126 comparison, clinical illness with SARS-CoV-1 was almost always severe, and RNAemia was be considered as a complementary modality for the early identification of individuals is limited by its single-center experience, and use of a convenience set of samples for 143 SARS-CoV-2 testing that favored overall selection of individuals with more severe disease given 144 the need for having had a blood sample collection. However, that a signal for ICU transfer was145 detected despite this patient selection lends further support to the clinical importance of RNAemia. 146 Furthermore, individuals in this cohort rapidly required ICU transfer from their time of arrival to 147 the hospital, such that plasma samples collected a single day before or on the same day as ICU 148 transfer reflect real-world experience. In addition, in the absence of viral culture data, it cannot be 149 determined at present whether detectable RNA represents intact infectious virus or inactive, non-150 replicating nucleic acid. A recent study attempted to address this question but failed to detect 151 SARS-CoV-2 RT-PCR in all serum samples such that culture could not be pursued. 9 Further work 152 should thus be performed to investigate this question given the potential important biosafety and 153 blood product transfusion implications, though non-severely ill individuals are less likely to be

TABREF0.text: determine the viability of virus, the presence of viral RNA in plasma is referred to as RNAemia instead of viremia. Sample size was based on a convenience set of all available clinical samples without formal power calculation. Statistical analysis was completed using Stata v15.1. Descriptive analysis was performed by Chi-squared test for categorical variables, or Fisher's exact test when there were less than 5 datapoints per cell, and by Mann-Whitney U test for continuous variables. A two-tailed p value of <0.05 was considered significant. This study was approved by the Stanford Institutional Review Board (protocol #48973). Written individual consent was waived
